Fándi, the commonest equivalent of 'fill', is the causative verb derived from fáa 'be full'. Fáa 'be full' is however a semi-labile verb, used transitively with a subject referring to a substance occupying a place (but not to an agent).

Láa (1) is a semi-labile verb whose precise meaning is 'lie' (intransitive) / 'lay' (transitive). In the transitive construction, the non-derived form is typically used with inanimate T's, whereas the causative form is preferred with animate T's.

In its primary meaning 'tie', siti is a plain transitive verb, but it also has the metaphorical meaning 'be ill-lucked', 'undergo difficulties', in which it has an intransitive construction which cannot be viewed as passive.
Another verb (soo) is used for 'pour into a container.
Soo is used exclusively for 'pour into a container'. In other situations, the equivalent of English 'pour' is boŋ.

Bula (1) is a semi-labile verb whose basic meaning is 'settle (somewhere)', and in transitive use 'A puts T somewhere'. This verb also constitutes the counterpart of 'A follows X', but in a different construction (see bula (2)).

Láa (1) is a semi-labile verb whose precise meaning is 'lie' (intransitive) / 'lay' (transitive). In the transitive construction, the non-derived form is typically used with inanimate T's, whereas the causative form is preferred with animate T's.

Ké 'put' is probably cognate with ké 'do, occur', and ké 'transform, become', but the analysis of the constructions in which these meanings are expressed justifies the recognition of three homonymous verbs.
Búŋ is a possible Mandinka equivalent of 'throw', but also of 'shoot', 'aim', 'sting'.

Samba 'bring, carry' is not oriented deictically. If the deictic orientation is not clear from the context, centripetal orientation can optionally be specified by adding the centripetal particle naŋ, or by using naa ... ti (lit. 'come with') instead of samba; centrifugal orientation can similarly be specified by using táa ... ti (lit. 'go with') instead of samba. The 3rd argument of samba can be a locative expression (coding frame A > T > V > L) or a recipient marked by the benefactive postposition ye (coding frame A > T > V R+ye).
Naa in the coding frame 1 > V (> LOC) is the counterpart of 'X comes (somewhere)'; it expresses 'bring' in combination with the postposition ti.

Samba 'bring, carry' is not oriented deictically. If the deictic orientation is not clear from the context, centripetal orientation can optionally be specified by adding the centripetal particle naŋ, or by using naa ... ti (lit. 'come with') instead of samba; centrifugal orientation can similarly be specified by using táa ... ti (lit. 'go with') instead of samba. The 3rd argument of samba can be a locative expression (coding frame A > T > V > L) or a recipient marked by the benefactive postposition ye (coding frame A > T > V R+ye).

This verb is basically the counterpart both of 'go', but also expresses 'carry' in combination with the postposition ti; the coding frame corresponding to 'S goes somewhere' has been selected; the coding frame corresponding to 'A carries T somewhere' is A > V > T+ti > L, lit. 'A goes with T somewhere'. Like naa 'come', táa has no causative form. Contrary to naa ... ti 'bring', táa ... ti 'carry' does not lend itself to Postposition Incorporation.

Só 'give' differs from díi 'give' not only in its alignment (indirective for díi, secundative for só), but also in its semantics: só implies that the theme will remain in the possession of the recipient, whereas díi carries no such implication.

Yitandi 'show, announce' is an exceptional case of a verb used with exactly the same meaning and the same syntactic properties in its non-derived form (yita) and in a form that seems to have been derived by means of a causative suffix (yitandi).
Suuñaa 'steal' derives from the noun suŋ 'thief'.
Mandinka has two verbs, nukuŋ and maabo, used in the same constructions with the meaning 'hide'. In addition to this meaning, maabo also expresses 'save', 'keep'.
Fíta 'wipe, sweep' can only be used in a construction in which the object refers to a surface from which something is removed. Another verb (kóŋkoŋ) must be used to specify the thing being removed.

Teyi 'cut' is used specifically with reference to plant stems (grass, rice, millet, reed, etc.); 'cut' in general is expressed as kuntu. Teyi 'cut' is cognate with teyi 'cross', but teyi 'cross' is an A-labile verb, whereas teyi 'cut' is a plain transitive verb. The homonymy between teyi 'cut' and teyi 'break' is the accidental result of phonetic changes (these two verbs have distinct forms in the other Manding varieties).

Mandinka has several possible equivalents of 'hit' or 'beat'. Búsa has been selected as expressing 'hit' or 'beat' without any additional shade of meaning or restriction on the nature of the participants. Iterativity can optionally be specified by using the reduplicated form búsámbúsaŋ.

Mandinka has several possible equivalents of 'hit' or 'beat'. Búsa has been selected as expressing 'hit' or 'beat' without any additional shade of meaning or restriction on the nature of the participants. Iterativity can optionally be specified by using the reduplicated form búsámbúsaŋ.
Faa is a labile verb; the coding frame corresponding to its transitive use has been arbitrarily selected, but faa with the coding frame S > V is also the counterpart of 'S dies'.
Káti 'break' is used for long and rigid objects. With 'one's eyes' in object function, káti means 'blink'.

Tóo láa can be described as a noun + verb compound (lit. 'put name') which taken as a whole constitutes the equivalent of a plain transitive verb; alternatively, from a strictly formal point of view, it is perfectly possible to consider that tóo 'name' is the object of láa 'put', and that the noun phrase preceding tóo is the genitival dependent of tóo.

Mandinka has two verbs with the meaning ‘call’: kíli and kúmándi. They can be used interchangeably in the same constructions. Formally, kúmándi is a causative verb derived from kúma ‘speak, talk’, but its synchronic meaning cannot be directly explained from this etymology.

Fó constitutes the counterpart of several meanings, with however the same coding frame. Mandinka also uses fó to express 'speak a language', but uses another verb (kúma 'produce a sound, speak') to express 'A talks (to X)' without specifying about what, and still another verb (láa) to express 'tell a story'. In Mandinka, clauses cannot occupy the subject or object position. Clausal complements occur in postverbal position, and if the verb is transitive, the complement clause is represented in the canonical object position by a cataphoric pronoun.
Semantically, láa(2) 'sing (a song), tell (a story)' can be viewed as a metaphorical extension of láa(1) 'lay'.

Fó constitutes the counterpart of several meanings, with however the same coding frame. Mandinka also uses fó to express 'speak a language', but uses another verb (kúma 'produce a sound, speak') to express 'A talks (to X)' without specifying about what, and still another verb (láa) to express 'tell a story'. In Mandinka, clauses cannot occupy the subject or object position. Clausal complements occur in postverbal position, and if the verb is transitive, the complement clause is represented in the canonical object position by a cataphoric pronoun.
This verb expresses more generally 'produce a sound'.
Silá-ndi is a causative verb regularly derived from sílaŋ 'fear'.
Lafi means 'want' and 'like'.
Kanu also means 'love'.

The basic meaning of this verb, cognate with the adjective díimaa 'pleasant, easy', is 'be pleasant', 'be easy'; in combination with the benefactive postposition ye, it constitutes a possible (and very common) counterpart of 'like'.

Deema is used both as a transitive verb (‘hunt’) and as a noun (‘hunting’, def. deem-ôo), hence its ability to be used without the antipassive marker -ri in the construction expressing de-specification of the object.

Beŋ 'meet' is an intransitive verb with an inherently reciprocal meaning, whose subject must represent a plural entity (possibly expressed as a coordinate phrase, A niŋ B). The same verb is however used transitively with the meaning 'wander round a place'.
Tara is a labile verb expressing 'be found' in its intransitive use, and 'find', 'meet' in its transitive use.

Báyíndi 'follow' is a lexicalized causative. Formally, it derives from báyi 'chase', but báyi and báyíndi have the same syntactic properties (both are plain transitive verbs), and the the difference in meaning cannot be related to any general semantic properties of regular causative verbs.

The basic meaning of bula is 'settle (somewhere)' (for its transitive use 'put somewhere, see bula (1)). Bula also constitutes the counterpart of 'A follows X' in a construction whose literal meaning is 'settle oneself on the track of' (coding frame A > V > X+nooma). This verb is also found in an idiom expressing 'remember' (Mandinka expresses 'X remembers Y' as 'X's mind settles at Y'). It is also productively used as a causative operator.
Mandinka has two verbs used in the same constructions with the same meaning 'help': máakóyi and deemaa.
Dómo 'eat' is the only Mandinka verb whose antipassive form (dómó-ri) is used not only as an action noun, but also as a verb.
In Mandinka, báluu 'be alive' is not used in the sense of 'live somewhere'. This meaning is most commonly rendered as sii.

The default interpretation of bori is 'run', but depending on the context, this verb can be used to denote any kind of relatively quick moment (roll, etc.). Bori is used transitively in the specialized meaning 'ride (a horse or a donkey), drive (a vehicle)' only, and even in this meaning, the causative form bori-ndi (also used with the meaning 'make run') can be used too.

Sawung expresses various meanings that can be considered as extensions of its basic meaning 'jump' (for example 'move to a new residence'), but in all its uses it remains a strictly intransitive verb.
In Mandinka, báluu 'be alive' is not used in the sense of 'live somewhere'. This meaning is most commonly rendered as sii.

Bó and fúnti are interchangeably used as intransitive verbs encoding movement from a closed space ('go out'), and by extension 'appear', but they behave differently with respect to causativization: fúnti is a strictly intransitive verb, whereas bó is a semi-labile verb.
Bó is a semi-labile verb. Used intransitively, it also means 'go out', 'appear', and used transitively, 'take off', 'remove'. The coding frame corresponding to 'appear' has arbitrarily been selected.

Saa and faa are used interchangeably as intransitive verbs expressing 'S dies', but saa is a strictly intransitive verb with no other possible construction, whereas faa is a labile verb also used transitively to express 'A kills P'.
Faa is a labile verb; the coding frame corresponding to its intransitive use has been selected arbitrarily, but faa with the coding frame 1 > 2 > V is also the counterpart of 'kill'.
The non-derived form boyi and the causative form boyi-ndi are both used transitively with the meaning 'fell'. Boyi ... kaŋ 'attack' (lit. 'fall on') lends itself to Postposition Incorporation.

Joloŋ 'fall' differs from boyi 'fall' both semantically (it expresses specifically 'fall vertically after detaching from a support') and syntactically (it has no causative form and its transitive use is fully productive).

Búsa (2) expresses specifically 'fall violently on something'. It can be viewed as a semantic extension of búsa (1) 'hit, beat', but its syntactic properties are different: búsa (1) is a plain transitive verb, whereas búsa (2) lends itself to Oblique/Object Alternation.
Kóŋko is more commonly used as a noun, and the commonest equivalent of 'E is hungry' is a construction whose literal meaning is 'Hunger is at E'.

Soto is a labile verb; in its transitive use, it expresses 'get' or 'have', whereas in its intransitive use, it can be glossed as 'be available'. The causative form soto-ndi expresses 'make available', 'provide'.

Dádaa expresses both 'make' and 'repair', but is fully productive in the sense of 'repair' only. In the sense of 'make', Mandinka rather tends to use either more specific verbs ('carve', 'sew', etc.), or the verb ké 'transform (into)'.

Ké( 2) is a semi-labile verb whose basic meaning is 'become' (intransitive) / 'transform into' (transitive). It also has a causative form expressing 'help to become'. In its intransitive use, it expresses 'be' in competition with the identificational copula mu.

The use of this verb with an ordinary NP in object function is not frequent. In the transitive construction, the object of míira is most of the time a pronoun anticipating a complement clause in dislocated position.
Mandinka has no verb expressing specifically 'hug'; the basic meaning of míniŋ is 'wind', so the 'hug' meaning arises from an intransitive version of this ("wind oneself around someone").

Dímiŋ is used in the same construction to express 'cause to feel pain', but the same meaning 'cause to feel pain' can also be expressed by the causative form dímí-ndi. This use of a causative form is irregular, since it involves no valency change and seems to depend, either on the nature of the term in subject function, or on an aspectual distinction.
Mandinka has three verbs expressing 'be/fall ill'. The three of them are plain intransitive verbs from which a transitive verb can be derived via Causative Derivation 1.
Mandinka uses another verb (mála) in the context 'The fire burns'.
Siŋ and wúri 'dig (for)' are used interchangeably in the same constructions.

Wóto is a bivalent verb whose construction cannot include a term expressing the thing being removed while peeling. In order to translate literally something like 'The boy peeled the bark off the tree', bóndi 'remove' must be used.
Bóndi does not express specifically 'peel', but more generally 'remove'. It derives from bó 'go out, leave'.
Líi 'shave' is a transitive verb with an obligatory object denoting either a body part or a person, represented as Z in the coding frame.

Ñori is a semi-labile verb; it is used intransitively with the meaning 'move' and transitively with the meaning 'push', but it also has a causative form ñori-ndi 'cause to move, postpone'. A spatial expression in oblique role would be assigned the role of source of movement, so that 'A pushes P somewhere' can only be expressed by combining 'push' with another verb assigning the role of destination.

This verb is basically the counterpart both of 'go', but also expresses 'carry' in combination with the postposition ti; the coding frame corresponding to 'S goes somewhere' has been selected; the coding frame corresponding to 'A carries T somewhere' is A > V > T+ti > L, lit. 'A goes with T somewhere'. Like naa 'come', táa has no causative form. Contrary to naa ... ti 'bring', táa ... ti 'carry' does not lend itself to Postposition Incorporation.

The default interpretation of bori is 'run', but depending on the context, this verb can be used to denote any kind of relatively quick moment (roll, etc.). Bori is used transitively in the specialized meaning 'ride (a horse or a donkey), drive (a vehicle)' only, and even in this meaning, the causative form bori-ndi (also used with the meaning 'make run') can be used too.

Karandi 'teach' is the causative verb derived from karaŋ 'learn'. Karaŋ 'learn' is cognate with karaŋ 'read' but has different syntactic properties (karaŋ 'read' is a plain transitive verb, whereas karang 'learn' lends itself to Introversive Alternation, and is causativized by means of the causative suffix typically used with intransitive verbs).
Nikindi 'teach' is the causative verb derived from nikiŋ 'learn'.
Sári constitutes the counterpart of two related meanings, 'scream' and 'shout at'.
Moyi has two causative forms: moyi-ndi (Causative Derivation 1) has the lexicalized meaning 'promise', whereas moyi-rindi (Causative Derivation 2) expresses 'make hear', 'tell'.
Lafi means 'want' and 'like'.
Súmbu is also the Mandinka counterpart of 'kiss'.

Duŋ 'dress' has an obvious semantic connection with duŋ 'enter', but the construction of duŋ 'dress' cannot be predicted from that of duŋ 'enter'. Duŋ 'dress' has an obligatory argument not included in the role frame 'A dresses P', represented as Z in the coding frame. By contrast, P in the construction of duŋ is optional, and its omission triggers a reflexive reading.
Sári constitutes the counterpart of two related meanings, 'scream' and 'shout at'.

Loo is a semi-labile verb with the basic meanings 'stand' and 'put in standing position'. It is found in transitive constructions with the meaning 'raise', 'erect' (and by extension 'organize an event', 'fix a date') either in its non-derived form or in a form including the causative suffix. The causative form seems to be preferred with objects that are not necessarily in vertical position, whereas the non-derived form refers to objects that, once erected, will normally remain in the same position. The non-derived form is also used with abstract objects.
In Mandinka, báluu 'be alive' is not used in the sense of 'live somewhere'. This meaning is most commonly rendered as sii.

Bó is a semi-labile verb. Used intransitively, it also means 'go out', 'appear', and used transitively, 'take off', 'remove'. The coding frame corresponding to 'leave a place' has arbitrarily been selected.

Bula (3) is a transitive verb whose precise meaning is 'abandon'. Depending on the semantic nature of its object, it does not necessarily imply movement. Although there is an obvious semantic connection with bula (1) 'settle; put', the constructions in which these two verbs occur would be difficult to analyze if they were viewed as a single verb.
This verb has been added in order to illustrate the case of a trivalent verb with no object and two oblique arguments.
This derives from the adjective súmaa 'cold'.
This verb cannot be used to express 'blink one's eyes' (expressed in Mandinka as lit. 'break one's eye')
This verb has a regular causative form báyíríndi 'cause to chase' and a lexicalized causative form báyíndi 'follow'.

When this verb is used transitively, the subject obligatorily represents the bridegroom. The relationship with the intransitive construction used with the name of the bride in subject function can be viewed as a particular case of the Active / Passive Alternation. A causative can be derived from fútuu (fútú-ndi), but it implies coercion (‘force someone to marry’), and cannot be used to express simply ‘x marries y to z’. On the expression of ‘x marries y to z’, see OFFER.
karaŋ 'read' is cognate with karaŋ 'learn', but these two verbs differ in their syntactic behavior. The behavior of karaŋ 'read' is that of a plain transitive verb.
With an object referring to a person, the usual interpretation of nii ‘offer’ is ‘marry (a girl)’.
This verb has two constructions in which it constitutes the counterpart of English 'cram' and 'stuff' respectively.

ké (3) is a labile verb used intransitively with the meaning 'happen, occur', and transitively with the meaning 'do'. It is probably cognate with ké (1) and ké (2) but has distinct syntactic properties. The use of ké (3) with the antipassive form of transitive verbs in object function is a common strategy for encoding two participant events without mentioning the patient.

Teyi 'cross' is cognate with teyi 'cut' but has distinct syntactic properties: teyi 'cut' is a plain transitive verb used intransitively with a passive meaning exclusively, whereas teyi 'cross' lends itself to Oblique/Object Alternation.
This verb is also used in meteorological expressions, with a noun referring to a meteorological phenomenon in subject function.
This verb has been added to the sample in order to illustrate the case of Mandinka verbs used exclusively in the middle construction.

Mandinka has two verbs with the meaning ‘call’: kíli and kúmándi. They can be used interchangeably in the same constructions. Formally, kúmándi is a causative verb derived from kúma ‘speak, talk’, but its synchronic meaning cannot be directly explained from this etymology.
Naa in the coding frame X > V (> L) is the counterpart of 'X comes (somewhere)'; it expresses 'bring' in combination with the postposition ti.
The precise meaning of this verb used transitively is 'A leaves T somewhere', but it has been added in order to illustrate the Subject / Oblique Alternation.
Complex verb. Lit. 'cover + PUT'. The UV is a stative (positional) predicate.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'full + PUT'. The coding frame for this complex verb, as well as the one formed with the Kriol translation equivalent bilimap 'fill' as uninflecting verb, is consistently 'A fills P into L'. Unfortunately I did not explore a potential alternation with L as direct object.

Complex verb. Lit. 'be in an open-top container or vessel + PUT'. The closest equivalent to 'load' thus refers to a configuration of the "load" in an open container. Another translation equivalent would be the same as under FILL.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'tied + PUT'. UV is monovalent and stative (i.e. a positional)
Complex Verb. Lit. 'wound.around + GET/HANDLE'. UV is monovalent and stative (i.e. a positional)
Complex verb. Lit. 'pour/spill + PUT'
Simple verb. More frequently in complex verbs with the uninflecting verb specifying the configuration or topological relation of T at L (e.g. 'inside', 'on top and supported')
Simple verb. Also (with same valency pattern) with coverb diwu 'fly, throw'.
Simple Verb. This is a transitive verb of accompanied motion; T is always direct object, R is optionally encoded with a dative NP; no alternation is possible.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'carry under one arm + TAKE'. Uninflecting verbs are lexically specific as to the manner of carrying, e.g. 'under one arm in a cooliman', 'on the shoulder', 'in both arms in front of body = hug', 'with a strap'. These are bivalent stative predicates which can also combine with ganimuwa 'HAVE'; the motion component is added by the inflecting verbs ganuga 'TAKE' or gananthamany 'BRING'. Since all of these behave the same in terms of valency, only one representative of the set has been entered here.
Complex Verb. LIt. 'send + PUT'
Simple Verb.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'show + PUT'.

Complex Verb, Lit. 'steal + ROB'. Examples also illustrate alternative complex verbs with the same inflecting verb and a small set of uninflecting verbs: birrg 'take away', burrb 'do to completion'. Ditransitive in all of these cases.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'steal + GET/HANDLE'. Alternates with ditransitive bunug ganiyunggany, lit. 'steal + ROB'.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'hidden PUT'

Complex Verb. Lit. 'come off + GET/HANDLE'. Source can be marked with Ablative or Translation equivalent was chosen here because of "removal" frame given with meaning label; the UV gub is a change of location predicate encoding detachment or removal from canonical place, such as yam from the ground, guts from an animal, leaf from plant; it is thus less specific than 'tear' and no direct translation equivalent. No more specific manner predicate was found in the data. Another UV lalarr used in "tearing" contexts has a more general meaning of 'scratch, sever'.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'wipe + HIT'. X, not T is the direct object.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'cut + HIT'. Alternative with inflecting verb meaning 'make an impact with an edge' also exists. Although the uninflecting coverb gad is phonologically identical to English 'cut' it is most likely an inherited lexical item (if it were a Kriol borrowing it would take the transitive suffix -im).
Complex Verb. Lit. 'touch + GET/HANDLE'
Simple Verb
Complex Verb. Lit. 'beat + HIT'. Nonreduplicated form not attested.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'break off + HIT'; thus also applicable to inanimates and more akin to 'finishing something off'. For an alternative restricted to animates, see digirrij ganima.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'die + HIT'. Choice of alternative inflecting verbs specifies instrument of killing, e.g. ganijjany 'POKE, USE POINTED INSTRUMENT', ganangu 'GET/HANDLE, USE HANDS', ganiwa 'BITE'. See also entry for 'DIE'.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'break + HIT'. Other IVs can be used depending on the manner of breaking.

Complex Verb. Figurative; lit. 'break + HIT'. Poorly attested in data, but seems to be specifically used for "naming a child after someone". For 'name' in the sense of 'call, conventionally use an existing name' see nij ganarram.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'be.named + PUT' = 'A call X Y'(by already established convention; not bestowing a name)'. Saying/using a name is expressed by nij ganangu, also illustrated in the examples.
Simple verb 'PUT' can also be used for 'naming'; equivalent to nij ganarrany.

Simple Verb. Highly polyfunctional verb which not only serves as a verb of quotation but is also used to express concepts of 'do', 'become', and in complex verbs, of 'internal causation', 'emission', 'internal motion', etc.
Complex verb. LIt. 'tell/discuss + PUT'. The object of discussion or "story" is encoded as direct object, the recipient as dative/oblique.
Complex verb. Lit. 'ask + PUT'.
Complex verb. Lit. 'talking + BE'. The UV yirrgbi is a monovalent activity predicate.
Complex verb. Lit 'be.knowledgable + BE'. The UV jurriya is stative and can also be used as predicate nominal in a verbless clause. Stative alternant of 'teach' (see jurriya ganangu).
Simple Verb (transitive).

Complex Verb. Lit. 'look at + SEE'. The UV is a monovalent stative predicate of direction of gaze. The intransitive alternant with inflecting verb gagba 'BE' is never used with a P but either with a dative NP ('look for X') or a directional (locative) NP ('look in direction X').

Complex Verb involving Kriol UV. Lit. 'frighten + GET/HANDLE'. All examples of 'frighten' in my data involve the Kriol borrowing. UV carries the Kriol transitivity marker and is a bivalent dynamic predicate.
Simple Verb (transitive). Very marginal in actual discourse and not used by all speakers. Alternative expression: see yarrajgu gagba.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'be afraid + BE'; 'be afraid of NP-DAT'. More frequent than transitive simple verb counterpart ganiyangmany.
Complex verb. Lit. 'like/want + GET/HANDLE'. The UV is a bivalent predicate.
Complex verb. Lit. 'hunt + GO'. The verb 'go' can also have a habitual meaning so the expression can translate 'be a hunter', i.e. 'go hunting habitually'.

Complex verb. Literally 'facing + GET/HANDLE', i.e. 'encounter someone facing them' or even more literally 'A affects someone in such a way that they are facing A'. The UV is a positional predicate meaning 'facing (ground)'.
There is no specific Jaminjung equivalent to purposeful meeting that I am aware of - the equivalent would be expressed by 'come to talk' or similar. The verbal correspondence selected here expresses encountering someone.
Simple Verb. (But also occurs in complex verbs with coverbs of manner and direction of motion, as in ex. 25).
Complex verb with Kriol-derived UV; no native Jaminjung equivalent attested.
Simple Verb (transitive). Has an atelic lexical alternant thawaya gagba 'eat + BE'.
Complex Verb. Lit 'eat + BE'. Lexical atelic alternant of simple verb ganimindany. P usually omitted - not counted as alternation here since NP omission is frequent.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'bathe + PUT', i.e. 'put in/under water'. The Uninflecting Verb ngabulg is a monovalent predicate of change of location, i.e. it denotes a spatial transfer into water, which is reflected in the choice of inflecting verb of transfer 'put', and of gardbany 'fall' for the intransitive alternant. Only used with animate undergoers; for 'wash' with inanimate undergoers see gulyu ganangu.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'wash, rinse + GET/HANDLE' (not used for animate undergoers; for which see ngabulg ganarrany). The UV is a bivalent activity predicate encoding a manner of affecting a P.
Complex verb. Lit. 'cough + SAY/DO'.
Complex verb. Lit. 'move upwards + GO'. Compatible with other, intransitive and transitive, verbs of locomotion.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'sit + FALL'. See also waga gagba 'sit'.
Complex verb. Lit. 'run + GO'. Compatible with other, intransitive and transitive, verbs of locomotion.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'jump + GO'. UV is monovalent and dynamic and unspecified for telicity (punctual vs. durative alternation also achieved by choice of different IVs not considered here).
Complex verb. Lit. 'sing + BE'
Simple Verb 'be in location'. With humans also complex verb waga gagba 'sit + BE'.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'appear + COME'. Alternatively, see also bul ganima 'appear + HIT', in an equally intransitive frame. Accomplishment (durative) equivalent of bul ganima.

Complex Verb, with transitive indexing but syntactically intransitive. Lit. 'appear + HIT'. Syntactically intransitive use of morphologically transitive verb 'HIT' in specialized sense with expressions of appearance. Achievement (punctual) equivalent of bul garumany.
Complex Verb. Lit. 'die GO'. See also entry for KILL.
Simple Verb.

Complex Verb. Lit. 'hold in arms in front of body + GET/HANDLE', i.e. 'A gets/holds P in his/her arms in front of him/her'. Collocation, with transitive indexing but syntactically intransitive. Lit. 'belly bad SAY/DO', i.e. 'be/have a bad stomach'. Possessor is core argument, body part additional absolutive argument. Complex Verb. Lit. 'be sick + BE'. Body part can be added as additional absolutive noun phrase, as in ex. 162. A marginal, non-productive type of inchoative alternation is (marginally) attested: warlad gardbany, lit. 'be sick + FALL' = 'fall ill'.

Presumably, these two verbs are best treated as independent lexical items, despite their morphological affinity.

The verb kowagaru 'fear' is morphologically derived from the adjective kowai 'be afraid'.

In Mandarin, the counterpart of COVER usually takes an applicative as a complement.

The Mandarin counterpart zhuāngmǎn is in nature a Verb-Complement structure, i.e. zhuāng+mǎn (lit. 'load/stuff+full'). Therefore, it can enter both BA abd BEI alternations. But for the same reason, as the result of 'filling' is present and clear, it cannot enter Middle Alternation. When used as a transitive verb, a pre-verbal PP is often used to indicate with what one fills something.

zhuāng is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as load. Often a PP is used pre-verbally to indicate the direction or loading or where something is placed. zhuāng can be followed by a complement, which is usually mǎn meaning full to indicate the result of loading, or sometimes shàng meaning onto or with. And that is why it can enter the BA and BEI alternations.
In Mandarin, an applicative is normally needed to convey aspectual information when shuan is used in alternation.
dào is used as a transitive verb, usually taking a pre-verbal PP to indicate direction of pouring. When used in BA and BEI constructions, a post-verbal PP is usually used for the same purpose.

The Mandarin counterpart of PUT is normally used together with two PPs with the counterpart being between them. Or a complement usually follows the Mandarin counterpart when it is used in an imperative sentence, like Ba shu fang-qilai, which means 'Put the book (in its right place.'. A more formal version of the Mandarin counterpart is fangzhi (lit. 'put-put'), but this property of compounding restricts its alternations.

rēng is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as throw. However, it in itself implicates the complement information just as away does in throw away. rēng is often used with a pre-verbal PP to indicate direction of throwing. When used in BA and BEI constructions, a post-verbal PP is possible, but using a pre-verbal PP is also possible.

Mandarin does not have a simple word that is the exact counterpart of BRING. The meaning of dai in Mandarin is only ‘carry’ or ‘take’, which does not denote directional information. The closest counterpart of BRING in Mandarin is a compound dai-lai (lit. 'carry–come'). The property of compounding restricts its alternations.

Mandarin dài is used as a transitive verb. It usually demands a complement to follow it indicating direction of movement. When this condition is satisfied, the verb can enter both BA and BEI altrnations.

fā is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as send. Usually using a PP is necessary to indicate the direction of sending. When the PP is placed post-verbally, it unambiguously indicates direction of sending, but when it is placed pre-verbally, it causes ambiguity. That is, it may have a beneficial meaning as well as a directional one. fā can be used ditransitively. Another possible Madanrin counterpart of send would be a compound fāsòng (lit. 'send-send').

gěi is a typical ditransitive verb and when it is used in BA or BEI constructions, an aspectual marker le is often used following either gěi or the VO structure. With the extension of the ditransitive constructional meaning, gěi has developed into not only a preposition indicating direction of transfer but also a causative marker.
In Mandarin, zhanshi normally goes together with a PP, and zhanshi is a compound meaning 'exhibit and show'. Therefore, no precise counterpart exists in Mandarin.

tōu is used mainly as a transitive verb in practically the same way as steal But a pre-verbal PP is often used to indicate the source of stealing. In BEI and BA alternations, tōu often is followed by an optional complement indicating the result or state of affairs. For that reason, tōu can be used ditransitively, as some linguists hold.
In Mandarin, the counterpart of HIDE usually takes an applicative in both Ba alternation and passive alternation.

sī is used as a transitive verb. As the verb in itself usually implicates the information of the end result of tearing, it does not need a complement to denote the result when it is used in BEI and BA constructions, though the use of the complement (e.g. sī pò , lit. 'tear-broken', or sī suì, lit 'tear-smashed') is also possible.

cā is used as a transitive verb in nearly the same way as wipe. Usually an optional complement morpheme like qù (lit. 'off') or diào (lit. 'lose') follows cā to indicate the end result of wiping. The morpheme is preferrable most probably because of phonological needs. cā is used more often in BA and BEI constructions. To express the English A wipes B off X, Mandarin speakers would use an modifier+N structure (i.e., X' B) as its object.

qiē is often used as a monotransitive verb. It can be used in a ditransitive construction because in a cutting event that something is removed from somewhere is implied, which denotes a potential semantic element of movement and transfer of something cut off. And that semantic feature to a certain extent accords with the constructional meaning of ditransitive construction.

(chù)mō functions largely in the same way as touch both semantically and syntactically. But Mandarin mō doesn't clearly denote the continuity or discontinuity of the action while touch strongly denotes the discreteness of the action, unlike feel. Therefore, mō can enter the Middle Construction whose constructional meaning requires a continuity interpretation of the action while touch usually cannot.
In Mandarin, the counterpart of HIT usually takes a complement in alternations.

pāidǎ (lit. 'pat-beat') in fact can be viewed as a hyponym of the superordinate beat because it means 'beat by patting', or'patting-like beating'. For the same reason it can also function as a noun. But in most cases, it is used as a monotransitive verb. Constrained by its two syllables, it is not very often used in BA or BEI alternations, in which a postverbal complement is usually necessary and the verb involved is usually monosyllablic.

shā is used as a transitive verb and implicates the result of killing, i.e. 'death', which is very similar to kill, but sometimes people use shā-sǐ (lit. 'kill-dead') to stress the result of 'death'. In that case, shā means the same as shā-sǐ. For that reason, shā can enter both the BA and BEI constructions where the use of the complement is optional. When used alone, shā often takes an aspectual marker le.
Mandarin does not have a simple word for BREAK. daduan is a compound which literally means 'hit and broken'.
Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for NAME. In Mandarin, a counterpart of NAME is a compound mingming (lit. 'name-a name'), which is a VO construction.

shuō is used generally as a transitive verb in very much the same way as say, and usually a pre-verbal PP is used to indicate to whom one says soemthing. Like pǎo 'run' and tiào 'jump', shuō can also enter VO structures holding various V-O semantic relationships.
gàosù is used mainly as a typical ditransitive verb just as tell is.

yào is used as a monotransitive verb, but it can enter a double object construction because its semantic features accord with the ditransitive constructional meaning. When used as a transitive verb, a preverbal PP is usually used and the most frequently-used prepositions are wèn and xiàng, which introduce the source of the transfer of its patient. When used in BA and BEI constructions, a complement is often necessary for syntactic and phonological reasons.

tán(huà) (lit. talk-talk or talk-words) is used as an intransitive verb but usually using a pre-verbal PP is necesary to indicate with or to whom one talks. The prepositions are usually tóng, hé, yǔ and gēn.

zhīdào is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as know is used. Interestingly, it can enter the BEI construction but not BA construction, because the two constructions have different meanings and semantic requirements.
kànjiàn literally means look-see and usually functions as a monotransitive verb meaning see.

kàn is used mainly as a transitive verb. Though it does not need a preposition to follow it as look does, a pre-verbal PP can be used to indicate the direction of looking. When used in BEI and BA constructions, a post-verbal complement is often used to indicate manner or result of looking.

xià(hu) is used as a monotransitive verb and functions in practically the same way as frighten. But the bisyllabic verb seems more formal than the monosyllabic one, which can take a complement to indicate the result or extent of 'frightening', for example, xiàzhao or xiàhuài (lit. 'frighten-broken') And it is only under that condition that the verb-complement structure can enter BA and BEI constructions, and Ambitransitive construction as well.
pà is used mainly as a transitive verb in nearly the same way as fear. It can also take a clausal object just like fear can.

xǐhuān is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as like. What is special about its usage is that it can take an object-like sentence, which calls forth heated discussion among syntactians. For instance, wǒ xǐhuān tā lǎoshí, (lit. 'I-like-he-honest') means 'I like it that he is an honest man.'.

pèngjiàn is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as English meet. It literally means 'meet-see', indicating a necessary result of meeting. For that reason, it can enter BEI alternation. Usually a pre-verbal PP is used to indicate where the meeting happens or with whom one meets.

gēn as a monosyllabic transitive verb functions in practically the same way as follow, but a more popular or frequently-used counterpart of FOLLOW in Mandarin would be gēnsuí (lit. 'follow-with') and gēnzōng (lit. 'follow-trace'). Those two bisyllabic verbs are more formal than gēn. When used in various constructions, gēn is usually followed by an aspectual marker -zhe or other complement indicating result of 'following', like shàng (lit. 'with') or diū (lit. 'lose'). And for that reason, it can enter such structures as BEI and BA constructions.

bāngzhù is used as a transitive verb, just like help, but in some dialects, it can be used in ditransitive construction denoting transfer, when it is understood through association because helping actions usually involve giving things to people in need. It seems many dialect speakers of Mandarin find the expression acceptable, but such a ditransitive use of bāngzhù is restricted among strict Putonghua speakers.

chī is used mainly as a transitive verb. When used in BA and BEI alternations, it is usually followed by a complement indicating result of the eating. The oblique object of chī 'eat' can be various and different. It can be a location, tool, source, etc.. for example, wǒ chī shítáng (lit. 'I eat cafeteria.') Only a few highly frequently used verbs permit such alternations. Another verb with the alternations is kǎo 'examine', whose object could be the subject of the examination, a school or college the entrance exam is taken for, or an academic degree, the credit of the exam. etc..

xǐ is used mainly as a transitive verb. As the verb in itself usually implies the result of washing, it does not need a complement when it is used in BA or BEI construction, though the use of it is also possible.
ké(sòu) is used as an intransitive verb, in practically the same way as cough is used.
pá can be used primarily as a monotransitive verb. And the action itself usually denotes continuity. For that reason, it can enter the Middle Alternation.

zuòxià is used as an intransitive verbal phrase in which xià (lit. 'down') indicates the result of sitting or the state of affairs. Therefore, a PP can be used pre-verbally to indicate where one sits down, but not post-verbally to indicate the result or state because xia in itself already indicates that. This explains why zuò can take a pre-verbal or post-verbal PP because zuò alone does not denote the result or state.

pǎo is used as an intransitive verb in practically the same way as run. Sometimes a pre-verbal or post-verbal PP is used to indicate directional or locative information. Just like tiào 'jump', pǎo is also very productive in forming VO structures with various types of V-O relationshiops, as a relic of archiac Chinese.
In Mandarin, the counterpart of JUMP normally takes a complement indicating aspect or directional movement.

chàng is used mainly as a transitive verb, but sometimes it may function as an intransitive one, omitting its object. A much better equivalent for sing used as an intransitive verb would be gēchàng (lit. 'sing-sing') which is a compound verb consisting of two synonymous verbs. But when it is reversed as chànggē (lit. 'sing-song'), it becomes a VO structure. gēchàng is more formal than chàng.

jūzhù consists of two morphemes which mean practically the same, i.e. 'live'. However, jūzhù is more formal than zhù and is more restricted in syntactic alternations. jūzhù is used as an intransitive verb and usually a PP is necessary to be placed pre-verbally or post-verbally. While zhù behaves in practically the same way, it can also function as a transitive verb, without using a preposition. For instance, wǒ zhù Běijīng (lit. 'I-live-Beijing') means 'I live in Beijing'.
chūxiàn well matches appear both semantically and syntactically, especially in that both words can enter the Locative Alternation. chūxiàn is used as an intransitive verb.

sǐ is used mainly as an intransitive verb in nearly the same way as 'die'. But in a special idiomatic VO construction it can take an object meaning 'lose or suffer the loss of (a close family member or someone or something that is dear to one who loses it)'. However, this VO structure is very special in that the verb does not have any transitivity or exert any force upon the object. For that reason, it seems that its use in Middle Construction with an applicative following the verb does not qualify as a true case.
In Mandarin, the counterpart of FALL usually takes a complement indicating result of falling. Therefore, it is more like a VP.
Mandarin leng can function as a predicate without a copular. The subject can be either animate or inanimate. Thus both wo leng ‘I am cold.’ and tianqi leng ‘The weather is cold.’ are grammatical.

è can be used both as an adjective and an intransitive verb, which is different from its English equivalent hungry. It can also enter a causative construction taking an object meaning literally 'to make sb hungry', i.e. 'to starve sb.'. That means it can function not only as an intransitive verb, but also a transitive verb. And this VO structure in turn can take a complement. This makes it possible that è can enter constructions like the Ambitransitive construction.
No verbal counterpart. The Mandarin counterpart of RAIN is only a noun. It usually takes a verb xia ‘drop’ in the sentence.
dédào is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as get. Usually a pre-verbal PP is used to indicate the source of getting something.

The alternations are in function close to the causative construction. V-de serves as a derived causative verb, and the verb indicates the manner of causative event. 哭得 could be paraphrased as 'to make with the manner of crying'.
In Mandarin, the counterpart of MAKE usually takes a complement indicating result of making in ba alternation and passive alternation.

xiǎng functions as a transitive verb and therefore takes an object without using a preposition as English think does. As a monosyllabic verb, it can take a complement to denote a resultative meaning. And for that reason, the verb-complement structure can usually apply to both BA and BEI alternations. And when used in the two alternations, the use of that verb-complement structure is necessary.

Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for SEARCH FOR. The meaning of sou in Mandarin is only 'search' or 'check'. The closest counterpart of SEARCH FOR in Mandarin is a compound sou-xun (lit. 'search–look for'). The property of compounding restricts its alternations.

yōngbào is used mainly as a transitive verb. Literally it means 'hug by holding out arms' where yōng seems redundant as an expression of manner of hugging. Sometimes an adverb hùxiāng or xiānghù (both meaning 'mutually') is used to modify yōngbào.
gǎndào téng functions in practically the same way as gǎndào lěng syntactically. Please refer back to the entry gǎndào lěng.

bēishāng is a typical adjective consisting of two synonymous morphemes meaning sad or sadness. It is used usually without a copular and can be modified by adverbs like hěn, fēicháng, etc. (both meaning 'very').

shēngbìng literally means 'beget-illness', which is most probably a causative construction as a relic of archiac Chinese, meaning 'to cause illness to turn out'. But in modern Chinese, it is used just as a somewhat lexicalized intransitive verbal phrase. When necessary, one can split up the phrase and insert aspectual markers like le or guo and modifers can be used to modify bìng ('illness') as in yī-chǎng-dà-bìng (lit. 'one-CL serious-illness'), meaning 'a serious disease'.

gān is a typical adjective and cannot enter constructions that typically permit verbs. However, many adjectives can function syntactically as verbs and for that reason they are treated as a subtype of verbs. For example, some adjectives can take aspectual markers like le indicating a result o state of affairs. But it is rather exceptional that gān can enter the Middle Construction. Despite the formal resemblance, the exerted force (i.e., 'causing to dry up') is an internal rather than external one. For that reason, it is not a true Middle Construction.

Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for LAUGH. The meaning of xiao in Mandarin is highly generalized, including the meanings of English laugh, smile, giggle, chuckle, grin, etc. Mandarin precise counterpart of LAUGH is a compound da-xiao (lit. 'big-smile'). The property of compounding restrictes its alternations. All the four alternations for xiao are not available to da-xiao.

(rán)shāo functions practically in the same way as burn both semantically and syntactically. While its semantic focus is on shāo ('burn'), rán means 'to catch fire'. Usually, ránshāo is more formal and used as an intransitive verb while shāo alone may function as both an intransitive and monotransitive verb. Interestingly, however interpreted, both ránshāo and shāo can enter the Middle alternation, with subtle semantic differences. Only the Middle construction with shāo is a true one.
shì gè lièrén (lit. 'be-a-hunter') is in itself a predicate, so it is impossible for any alternations.
Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for TAKE. The meaning of the compound nazou in Mandarin is ‘take away’. The property of compounding restricts its alternations. See BRING.

wā is used mainly as a monotransitive verb. However, the verb-object relations can vary, in that the object can be a patient, end product, tool, etc. In a typical digging event, one can dig up something and take it away. Therefore, an optional monosyllabic complement zǒu (lit. 'away') indicating direction can follow it to form a rather loose compound verb. For that reason, sometimes wā or wāzǒu can enter the Ditransitive Alternation.

xiāo is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as peel. Usually a pre-verbal PP is used to indicate other relevant information. VO construction involving xiāo can hold various semantic relationships, thus it can enter various alternations. Please note that in the BEI and BA constructions, a split VO structure is also possible when an aspectual marker le is used, mainly post-verbally.

Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for GRIND. The meaning of mo in Mandarin simply denotes the action of grinding, but it does not necessarily denote the result of it. Mandarin precise counterpart of GRIND is a compound mo-sui (lit. 'grind-smashed'). The property of compounding restricts its alternations. When used in alternations, mo is normally followed by a complement indicating result of grinding.

guā is used as a transitive verb in the same way as shave. It is most probably because that this verb can hold various V-O relationships just as pǎo, chī and tiào do, it may enter Middle construction in at least two ways, when the object can be a patient or a tool.
tuī is used as a transitive verb, whose syntactic behavior is very similar to that of dào. When tuī is used in BEI and BA alternations, generally using a complement or PP to follow it is necessary.

qù is used as a monotransitive verb in Mandarin and, unlike go, it takes an object directly without using a preposition. However, qù can also act as a directional verbal morpheme that is followed by a content verb denoting the purpose to do something. And in that case, the structure is more like a serial verb construction.

gǔn(dòng) literally means 'roll (move)', which is more formal than gǔn, but gǔn(dòng) when used as a verb, the meaning focus is put on 'roll' which necessarily entails the meaning of 'move'. gǔn is usually used as an intransitive verb in practically the same way as roll, but it can also enter a VO structure carrying a causative meaning. In that case, it is used as a transitive verb.

jiāo is used mainly as a transitive verb just as teach is, but it can also be used ditransitively. When used in BA and BEI constructions, using a complement or PP is usually necesary to indicate the result of teaching or direction of transferring knowledge or skills. jiāo can hold various types of relationships with its object.

There is no exact Mandarin counterpart of English scream. The closest translation jianjiao is a compound, where jian is an adjective meaning ‘sharp’. Therefore, jianjiao really means ‘cry sharply’. This characteristic of compounds restricts its application to relevant alternations, especially resultative alternations, which prohibits the verb's taking any manner adverbial.

Mandarin does not have a simple word that is the exact counterpart of COOK. The meaning of zhu in Mandarin just denotes one of the many ways of cooking. Mandarin precise counterpart of COOK is a compound peng-tiao (lit. 'cook-flavor'). The property of compounding restrictes its alternations.

tīngjiàn (lit. 'listen-hear') functions very much like kànjiàn 'see', where jiàn actually denotes the positive result of the action (of 'listening' or 'looking'). However, the semantic focus is laid on the result indicated by jiàn. Please refer to the entry of kànjiàn.

chén is used mainly as an instransitive verb. However, as an old conventional use, it may enter a causative VO construction as a transitive verb. As the VO construction may be associated with 'causing someone to lose sth', which accords with the ditransitive constructional meaning, the verb can also be used ditransitively.

Of a wide variety of meaning items of kāi, the basic meaning is 'open'. kāi is a neutral equivalent for boil and functions in practically the same way as it syntactically. The more formal equivalent would be fèiténg and the more informal version would be gǔn as used in some dialects. Unlike English boil, kāi cannot be used as a monotransitive verb, let alone a ditransitive one, which is probably due to the fact that kāi cannot be used causatively and Mandarin does not permit benefactive ditransitive construction.

wén matches smell closely both semantically and syntactically. When used in BA and BEI constructions, wén is usually followed by a complement to indicate manner of smelling, for syntactic and phonological reasons.
Mandarin does not have the counterpart of DRESS. The closest form is chuan-yifu (穿衣服), which is a VO construction. Therefore, this item is not included in this data base.
Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for SHOUT AT. In Mandarin, a PP is needed for the expression of AT. hechi just means 'reproach'.

jiàn(zào) functions in the same way as build both syntactically and semantically. It is in itself a compound verb, consisting of the two synonymous verbs jiàn and zào, both meaning 'build'. Both jiàn and zào can be used independently, but the former is more formal than the latter. And jiànzào is the most formal one. When used in BA or BEI constructions, a complement is often used for syntactic and phonological reasons.

zuò is used mainly as an intransitive verb in practically the same way as sit. But a PP can be used pre-verbally or post-verbally to indicate where one sits. Sometimes it can be used as a transitive verb, taking a place as its object. When used in BA and BEI alternations, zuo is preferably followed by a complement indicating result or duration of the sitting, etc.

líkāi is used as a transitive verb in practically the same way as leave both semantically and syntactically. But to mean 'leave for', Mandarin speakers use líkāi 'somewhere', qù 'somewhere else' (please refer to qù entry).

wán is used as a transitive verb without using a preposition, unlike play. It can also function as an intransitive verb. Usually, a pre-verbal PP is used to indicate relevant information, like where or with whom one plays. When transitive wán is used in BEI and BA alternations, a complement is usually used to follow it, indicating the result caused by playing.
Mandarin does not have the counterpart of BLINK. The closest form is zha-yan, which is a VO construction. Therefore, this item is not included in this data base.
root baju

Bò 'cover' like its synonym dé (see relevant record) is used transitively. The theme is basically introduced by fi. However, in an alternate construction, the theme is introduced by ní. Of the two forms, only bò occurs in the Inchoative-causative alternation. Both occur in the Possessive alternation and the Fi-ní alternation.

Dé 'cover' like its synonym bò (see relevant record) is used transitively. The theme is basically introduced by fi. However, in an alternate construction, the theme is introduced by ní. Of the two forms, only bò occurs in the Inchoative-causative alternation. Both occur in the Possessive alternation and the Fi-ní alternation.

A bipartite verb; the object is always inserted between the two halves of the verb. Its synonym is ro̩...kún (see relevant record). The choice of both forms of the verb is determined by the size of the 'entrance' of the object, a wide entrance versus a narrow entrance. Po̩n...kún is used for the former, while ro̩...kun is used for the latter.

A bipartite verb; the object is always inserted between the two halves of the verb. Its synonym is po̩n...kún (see relevant record). The choice between the two verbs is determined by the size of the 'entrance' of the object, a wide entrance versus a narrow entrance. Po̩n...kún is used for the former, while ro̩...kun is used for the latter.

The expression of 'load' in Yoruba involves the combination of the 'pack' verb kó, with either of the locative prepositions sí or lé. Sí expresses an interior location, while lé expresses and exterior location, especially 'on' an object.

Dè 'tie' like its synonym so (see relevant record) is a transitive verb. However, while the dè form can occur in both the Inchoative-causative and Fi-ní alternations, the so form on the other hand can only occur in the Fi-ní alternation.

So 'tie', like its synonym dè (see relevant record), is a transitive verb. However, while the dè form can occur in both the Inchoative-causative and Fi-ní alternations, the so form can only occur in the Fi-ní alternation.

Dà 'pour' like its synonym ro̩ (see relevant record) is used transitively. When a location is included, the choice of relevant preposition is determined by whether the theme is poured "in" or poured "on". If the former, sí is used; and if the latter, lé is used. Furthermore, the choice between dà and ro̩ is determined by the size of the 'entrance' of the object. For an object with a narrow entrance, e.g., a bottle, ro̩ is used. But if the entrance is wide, e.g., a bucket or a bushel, dà is used. Also, both forms occur in the possessive alternation; however, only dà occurs in the Inchoative-causative alternation.

Ro̩ 'pour' like its synonym dà (see relevant record) is used transitively. When a location is included, the choice of relevant preposition is determined by whether the theme is poured "in" or poured "on". If the former, sí is used; and if the latter, lé is used. Furthermore, the choice of dà or ro̩ is determined by the size of the 'entrance' of the object. For an object with a narrow entrance, e.g., a bottle, ro̩ is used. But if the entrance is wide, e.g., a bucket or a bushel, dà is used. Also, both forms occur in the possessive alternation; however, only dà occurs in the Inchoative-causative alternation.

The meaning 'put' in Yoruba expressed by combining fi with a relevant locative preposition, such as sí or lé. There is a possessive alternation with this verb; but this is marginal, as it is restricted to a possessive situation.
This is a transitive verb. Optional participants, e.g. the goal, can either be introduced by a prepositions, e.g., sí 'at', 'to', or by a verbal element, e.g., bá 'meet', lù 'hit'.
A bipartite verb; the theme argument is inserted between the two verbal parts. If a recipient is included, it will be introduced by the preposition fún.
This is a transitive verb.

This is a three-argument verb; in the basic construction, the theme is introduced by fi, while the recipient is introduced by sí. However, it occurs in the Recipient-dropping alternation, in which sí and its argument can be dropped. The understanding is that the recipient can be contextually inferred, but not the theme.
This is a ditransitive verb; the basic construction involves the use of ní to introduce the theme. In the alternate construction, the theme is introduced by fi.

This is a ditransitive verb; the theme is usually introduced by fi. However, there is one fixed expression in the language in which ní is used to introduce the theme. This is a highly marginal construction.
A transitive verb; if the construction expresses a possession, a possessive alternation can be realized.

A bipartite verb; the object of the verb is sometimes inserted between the two halves of the verb in a construction that appears like a serial verb construction i.e., NP pa NP mó̩. This is the basic construction. There is also the alternate construction in which fi is used to introduce the theme. In this construction the form of the verb is preserved as a single unit.

This is a transitive verb, but it can be used intransitively under the inchoative-causative alternation. It can also occur in the possessive alternation (external possession), i.e., if the construction expresses a possession.
This is a transitive verb. However, It is common for speakers to modify the verb with the clause-final adverb nù 'away'.

This is a transitive verb, but it can be used as intransitive under the inchoative-causative alternation. If an instrument is mentioned, it is introduced by fi. It also undergoes the Fi-ní alternation and the possessive alternation involving an external possession.

This is a transitive, <NP V NP>; and it has the same distribution as its counterpart bà (see relevant record). The instrument argument is introduced by fi in the basic construction. The verb can also occur in both the possessive and Fi-ní alternations.

This is a transitive verb, which has the same distribution as its synonym kàn (see relevant record). The instrument argument is introduced by fi in the basic construction. The verb can also occur in both the possessive and Fi-ní alternations.

A transitive verb; in the basic construction, the instrument argument is introduced by fi. Of the two verbs with the meaning HIT, only gbá occurs in the possessive alternation and in the Fi-ní alternation.

This is a transitive verb. Like its synonym gbá, in the basic construction, the instrument argument is introduced by fi. But of the two verbs with the meaning 'hit', only gbá occurs in the possessive alternation and in the Fi-ní alternation (see relevant record).

This is a transitive verb. It has the same syntactic distribution as its synonym nà (see relevant record). If an instrument is mentioned, it is introduced by fi in the basic construction. In the alternate construction, the instrument argument is introduced by ní. It also occurs in the possessive alternation (external possession).

This is a transitive verb. It has the same syntactic distribution as its synonym lù (see relevant record). If an instrument is mentioned, it is introduced by fi in the basic construction. In the alternate construction, the instrument argument is introduced by ní. It also occurs in the possessive alternation (external possession).

This is a transitive verb; if the instrument is mentioned, it can only be introduced by fi. There is no ní alternate. A possessive alternation is possible (i.e., external possession) if the construction expresses a possession (e.g. 'The doctor killed my child').

Fó̩, like its synonyms dá and kán (see relevant records), is a transitive verb; but can be used intransitively (Inchoative-causative alternation). It can also occur in the possessive alternation. The choice between the different 'break' verbs is determined by the shape of the object. E.g., fó̩ is used if the object is glass, round or cylindrical, while kán and dá are used for objects like stick, bone (leg or arm) etc.

D̩á, like its synonyms fó̩ and kán (see relevant records), is a transitive verb; but it can be used intransitively (inchoative-causative alternation). It can also occur in the Possessive alternation. The choice between the different verbs for 'break' in Yoruba is determined by the shape of the object. E.g., fó̩ is used if the object is glass, round or cylindrical, while kán and dá are used for objects like stick, bone (leg or arm) etc.

Kán, like its synonyms fó̩ and dá (see relevant records), is a transitive verb; but can be used intransitively (Inchoative-causative alternation). It can also occur in the Possessive alternation. The choice between the different verbs for 'break' in Yoruba is determined by the shape of the object. E.g., fó̩ is used if the object is glass, round or cylindrical, while kán and dá are used for objects like stick, bone (leg or arm) etc.

This verb like its synonym pè (see relevant record) are ditransitive verbs. The third argument, i.e., the name, is introduced by the preposition ní. Also, like its synonym pè, the verb occurs in the Ní-fi alternation.

This verb, like its synonym so̩ (see relevant record), is a ditransitive verbs. The third argument, i.e., the name, is introduced by the preposition ní. Also, like its synonym the verb occurs in the Ní-fi alternation.
This is a ditransitive verb in which the recipient is introduced by the preposition fún. The verb also has a marginal theme-dropping alternation.

This is a transitive verb. In Yoruba, the regular verb of inquiry béèrè 'ask' is different from the request verb to̩ro̩ which translates to 'beg' in English. When the source argument is mentioned, it is always introduced by the preposition ní.
This is a bipartite verb, comprising of the verbal parts bá and so̩, and the inherent NP ò̩rò̩ 'word'. The object of the verb is always inserted in between the two verbal halves of the verb.
This is a transitive verb.
This is a transitive verb.
This is a transitive verb.
This is a transitive verb.
This is a transitive verb. It also occurs in the symmetrical alternation.
This is a transitive verb.
This verb and its synonym bá are used transitively (see relevant record). Both forms always make use of the preposition ní to introduce a locative argument.
Bá like its synonym pàdé (see relevant record) is used transitively. Both forms always make use of the preposition ní to introduce a locative argument.
This is a transitive verb.
This is a bipartite verb, comprising of the verb root ràn + the preposition ní + the inherent NP o̩wó̩ 'hand'. The object of the verb is inserted in between the verbal half and the PP.
This is a transitive verb; if the verb has a direct object with a possessive construction, it can occur in the possessive alternation.
This is a transitive verb.

A transitive verb; but can also be used intransitively in the inchoative-causative alternation involving a patientive subject. The verb meaning itself is 'bathe'. Unlike its variant fò̩, it is always used in connection with animate referents, alive or dead, and sometimes body parts, e.g. hand(s), leg(s) and the face.

This is a transitive verb. The internal structure of the verb includes the verb root wú 'dig up', and the reduced form of the NP ikó̩ 'cough'. The verb also occurs in the symmetrical verb alternation.
This is a transitive verb. It can occur in the possessive alternation if the construction expresses a possession.
Normally a transitive verb; and its internal structure consists of the verb root sá 'run' and the NP eré 'race'. However, the verb root alone may be used as an intransitive verb.

Fòsókè like its synonym bé̩sílè̩ (see relevant record) has a complex morphology, consisting of the verb root fò 'fly', the preposition sí and the inherent locative NP òkè 'up'. The choice between the two verbs is determined by the direction of the action, whether upward (fòsókè), or downward (bé̩sílè̩).

Bé̩sílè̩ 'jump', like its synonym fòsókè has a complex morphology, consisting of the verb root bé̩ 'dive', the preposition sí, which is followed by the NP locative argument ilè̩ 'ground'. The choice between the two verbs is determined by the direction of the action, whether upward (fòsókè), or downward (bé̩sílè̩).

A transitive verb with an inherent NP complement. The internal structure of the verb consists of the verb root ko̩ 'to crow', and the NP object orin 'song'. The verb can occur in the possessive alternation if the sentence expresses a possession. E.g. Ade sang my song.
This is an intransitive verb; the locative argument is always introduced by the preposition ní.

A tripartite verb; the internal structure of the verb consists of fi+ara 'body' +hàn 'show'. If the recipient is included, it must be introduced by the preposition fún. However, the preposition marker can be dropped in the preposition-dropping alternation.
This is an intransitive verb.
This is an intransitive verb.

This is a transitive verb with a complex internal structure. It consists of the verb root mú 'catch', and the inherent NP complement òtútù. The verb can also be used in the symmetrical verb alternation.
A transitive verb; its internal structure consists of the verb root pa 'to kill', and the inherent NP ebi 'hunger'. This verb can also be used in the symmetrical verb alternation.
This is a zero argument verb.
A transitive verb; if the source argument is included, it can only be introduced by the preposition ní.
This is a transitive verb with internal structure: it consists of the verb root sun 'to ooze', and the inherent NP e̩kún 'lamentation'.
In a basic construction, the expression of MAKE in Yoruba consists of combining fi with the 'do' verb. However, s̩e can occur alone but in an alternate construction, i.e., in the Fi-ní alternation.
This verb combines with either of the prepositions nípa 'about' or sí. However, in the preposition-dropping alternation, the variant form rò is used. The meaning of the construction remains the same.
This is a transitive verb.
Sometimes simply pronounced dìmó̩. A transitive verb.

A complex tripartite verb; its internal structure consists of the meaningless verb particle ba, the NP inú 'belly' and the meaningless jé̩. The particles ba and je̩ can combine as bàjé to express the meaning 'spoil' or 'damage'. This verb can also be used in the symmetrical alternation.

A symmetrical verb; the internal structure of the verb includes the verb root s̩e 'to do / to make', and the inherent NP àárè̩. The position of the inherent NP can be changed without affecting the meaning of the sentence.
This is an intransitive verb.
A transitive verb; the internal structure of the verb consists of the verb root rín 'to laugh' and è̩rín 'laughter'.
This verb is basically an intransitive verb. However, it has a transitive alternant.
This is a transitive verb; if the source argument is included in the construction, it is always introduced by ní.

This is a transitive verb. As for the meaning 'dig for something', the only way to express it in Yoruba is to say 'X digs Y's hole' (see example). For 'dig for a material', e.g. gold, Yoruba will use the LOOK or SEARCH verb wá, sometimes combining with a Locative phrase 'X wá Y (ní ilè)' X looks for Y from the ground'.
A transitive verb; it can also be used intransitively under the inchoative-causative alternation. It can also occur in the Possessive alternation if the basic construction expresses a possession.
This is basically a transitive verb. However, if an instrument is mentioned, it must be introduced by fi.
This is a transitive verb; if the verb has a direct object with a possessive construction, it can occur in the possessive alternation.
A transitive verb; if a location is mentioned, it must be introduced by the preposition sí.
The locative argument of this verb is always introduced by the preposition sí. It can also be used intransitively, because the locative argument can be contextually inferred.
Can be used intransitively, and also transitively.

A ditransitive verb; the theme argument is introduced by the preposition ní, and can be dropped in the Theme-dropping alternation, but the meaning of the sentence is the same as the one with the theme.
This is an intransitive verb.

'Cook' can be sè or dáná. Only sè is used transitively, while dáná is intransitive. The dáná form consists of the verb root dá 'to create', and an inherent object iná 'fire'. Only sè can occur in the Inchoative-causative alternation. With both verbs, if a recipient is included, it must be introduced by the preposition fún.

'Cook' can be sè or dáná. Only sè is used transitively, while dáná is intransitive. The dáná form consists of the verb root dá 'to create', and an inherent object iná 'fire'. Only sè can occur in the Inchoative-causative alternation. With both verbs, if a recipient is included, it must be introduced by the preposition fún.
This is a transitive verb.
Sometimes, the verb is used transitively; sometimes it combines with another verb in a serial construction, and other times, it takes an infinitive clause as its object.
This is an intransitive verb.
This is an intransitive verb.

An ambitransitive verb; can be used transitively and intransitively. But mostly used intransitively. When used transitively (and with an agentive sense), it is often the case that the matrix verb is modified by wò 'look' in the same clause (NP V NP V). The construction thus has the literal sense 'smell X look'. Also, the verb can combine with the allative sí (see examples).

The verb can be used transitively and intransitively. When used as transitive, the object must be introduced by the donative preposition fún. This verb like its synonym jágbe (see relevant record), is a complex transitive verb, which morphologically consists of a transitive verb root and an inherent object.
